 This brings up an interesting issue. Namely, would a hypothetical alien race need to have a moral stance based on benevolent and compassionate principles in order to flourish and survive? I suspect that it doesn't. 
 
 I would think that there would have to be a sufficient level of intra-group cooperation for a particular group to flourish but many human groups have flourished well at the expense of other groups, showing that inter-group cooperation may not be necessary - ex. Rome exploited its empire, Spain and Portugal exploited the natives of Central and South America, etc. 
 
 I would also think that there would have to be some structure by which positions of authority or opportunities would be at least partly determined by merit. However, this says nothing about the treatment of those with less merit, who would be vulnerable to exploitation.
 
 So, though I would hope otherwise, I suspect that a moral stance of benevolence toward others would not be a requirement for a technologically advanced extra-terrestrial species.
